City of Wilmington
Wilmington, NC

Executive Summary -2004

The City of Wilmington has implemented a comprehensive program to safely manage chlorine at its two wastewater treatment plants located in the City of Wilmington. There have been no chlorine incidents in the most recent Five-Year history period.

In 1996, a Process Safety Management (PSM) program was initiated at the Plants. A PSM Implementation Manual was edited to be site specific for each Water Plant. The Manual was issued to the plants. In 1999 the Manual was expanded to address the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP).

Key items included in the updated manual are:

o A written Management Program defining the positions and individuals responsible for implementing the RMP and PSM regulations

o Written site specific procedures for Employee Involvement, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Pre-Startup Reviews and Self Audits

o Chlorine safety information as required by the regulations

o Standard Operating Procedures for safe Chlorine Management

o A Mechanical Integrity Program for chlorine equipment 

o An Emergency Response Plan to address chlorine emergencies and offsite response and communication

Next, these steps have been continually implemented to maintain compliance with the PMP/PSM program.

o Training on RMP/PSM and its key components including Management of Change, Mechanical Integrity and Incident Investigation;

o Conducting periodically Process Hazards Analyses for the two chlorine processes;

o Implementing the Mechanical Integrity Program for chlorine regulators, controls and material handling equipments such as cranes

o Conducting Self Audits to review compliance with the elements of RMP and PSM

o Conducting Chlorine Response Drills.

o Performing an annual review of our Chlorine Operating Procedures

The supervisors, chief operators and several plant operators meet several times per year to review and update procedures and to maintain compliance with all aspects of the RMP/PS

M regulation.

In addition to RMP/PSM compliance, the plants have implemented a number of programs to improve the safe handling of chlorine.

o The chlorine delivery systems at the plants have been upgraded to vacuum processes over the past 15 years. This process has proven to greatly reduce leaks by reducing the amount of equipment that is exposed to pressurized chlorine.

o  Chlorine leak detection alarm systems have been upgraded at both plants. These systems will allow an early detection and response to any chlorine leak.

Future capital projects to be implemented over the next 5 years anticipate replacing chlorine with an alternate method of disinfection.

The site's Emergency Response Plans have been significantly upgraded. In 1997, the ERP was revised to include offsite response and communication.  Chlorine Response Drills have been routinely conducted since 1998. 

In addition to Process Safety Management, an active safety program exists at the City, Public Utilities Department, Wastewater Treatment Division, and Section levels.  The Wastewater Treatment Division Safety Committee incorporates two components ? a committee comprised of its supervisors (7) and a committee composed of selected supervisors and subordinate staff members (7).  The division conducts a monthly safety meeting on a regulatory subject or other specific wastewater safety issues.  The Wastewater Treatment Division?s three sections ? Northside Operations, Southside Operations, and Wastewater Maintenance ? meet several times each month to discuss safety topics of relevance and particular interest to their respective activities.

o Conducting accident reviews for responsibility/prevention/minimization;
o Conducting safety inspections for all WWTD facilities;
